texts.en:
Sana is a 43-year-old married woman from Al-Hashmi-Amman, Jordan and a mother of three children.

Sana is requesting a loan of 700 JD to do home maintenance.

Sana is looking to improve her family living standards.

loans.use: to do home maintenance

loans.name: Kiwambi Cha Ujamaa Ugogo Group

texts.en:
Lambertha is a 35-year-old mother of four children, three of whom attend secondary school. She has been growing coffee, maize, beans and cassava for over 25 years. She is facing farming problems due to lack of fertilizers and crop diseases.
Lambertha is requesting a loan to purchase fertilizers and insecticides. She is working hard with the aim of being able to pay for food, clothes and medical expenses.

loans.use: to pay for fertilizers and insecticides.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is a farmer living in the Kapsowar area of Kenya. She is blessed with a lovely family. 

Susan has been a farmer for 10 years. Her primary source of income comes from the sale of milk and a variety of crops that she plants. She enjoys farming because she earns a living out of it, but her main challenge is the lack of a fence. 

Susan respectfully requests a loan to buy a fence. She wants to control her cows from going onto other people's land hence creating conflicts with neighbours. 

Susan chose Juhudi Kilimo because they help the farmers to undertake their projects with the loans they give them. During the training given, she learned that MFIs do help the poor with ways in which they can improve their income. 

This loan will bring an improvement in the life of Susan because she will never suffer losses that she used to suffer while paying for damages that her cows had caused.

loans.use: To buy a fence

loans.name: Lợi's Group

texts.en:
Mrs Lợi is 38 years old and she is married with 2 children.
 
She has operated a food stall/restaurant selling fish for more than 10 years.
Lợi lives in Trieu Son district, a  rural town in Thanh Hoa province.
Her family is a low-income household in village, moreover the market need is low in this region. 
In 2014, Lợi joined Thanh Hoa microfinance institution to improve her  business. Lợi has successfully repaid 2 loans from Thanh Hoa microfinance institution.
Lợi is a reputable person in the community. She is the leader of her solidarity group. 
The main hardship that Lợi faces is lack of capital.  She is requesting a loan to purchase more baby fish to resell.
With her business profit, Lợi hopes for her business to do well, for her family to be healthy and happy, and for her children to do well in school.

loans.use: to purchase more baby fish to resell

loans.name: Sara

texts.en: Sara operates a community phone center. Her resolve to operate other centers has led her to request a loan amount of $1075 to extend her operations to 3 other adjoining communities. She has participated in Krabans Business Advisory lessons.

loans.use: Communication Services

loans.name: Tha

texts.en:
Tha S. is 26 years old and sells fish at a stall at the Olympic Market in Phnom Penh. On the side, she and her husband raise cows and pigs which they plan to sell to a butcher at the market in the near future. The couple is able to generate between $10 and $20 of income per day, but average only $5 profit each day. After deducting the cost of renting her stall at the market ($20/month), S. and her husband struggle to support their two young children.

With this loan, S. hopes to buy her stall at the market outright so that she no longer has to pay the fee to rent it. Additionally, she hopes to expand her animal-raising business.

loans.use: To expand fish-selling business

loans.name: Chrisantus

texts.en:
Thirty-nine-year-old Chrisantus is married and has three children. He is unemployed and has been barely surviving with his family and wife who is always sick. Unable to raise business capital on his own, he came for assistance from GHAPE when he joined the program in the year 2000 and received his first loan of $30 which he used in opening up a small poultry business.

Since then, Chrisantus has received loans worth $900 and his community has been benefiting a lot from him in terms of manure which has undoubtedly increased food production. The profit he has been getting from his business is used to provide for his children’s school needs and his extended family.

Given this loan of $500, Chrisantus plans to expand the size of his poultry business and keep more goats to meet the increased demand. There is a ready market for his products and with his knowledge and skill in this field together with the training he has acquired from GHAPE, this business will undoubtedly be a success. Chrisantus plans to repay the loan in a timely manner.

loans.use: Rearing of goats and fowls

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria T. R. , 38, has a little store (a tienda) up in the hills above Nebaj. Her house and store are surrounded by cornfields, but her family does not own any land beyond their house. She opened the tienda two years ago when she received her first loan. In her tienda she sells water, juice, bananas, oil, salt, fruits and other staples that her neighbors will stop by and purchase. Because there is not much work for the people in her town, they did not have money to buy her weavings so she turned to operating a tienda as a continuing source of income.

Maria is married and has 7 children. The youngest two school-age children have not started school yet because she does not have the money for clothes and school supplies. She herself never attended school and therefore cannot read, write, or do addition. Her older children help her in the tienda when there are sums to be done. Their schooling is already paying off.

Maria does still do some weaving. Her specialty is weaving huipils, a traditional top worn by most women in the village of Nebaj. She can produce one in 15 days and sells in the market for up to US$200.

Even though her husband makes money driving a little three-wheeled taxi (called a tuc-tuc, pronounced Tuuk-Tuuk), her dream is to have enough food daily to feed her family. A major struggle is buying medicine for when a member of her family is ill which luckily is not often. As they say here, "Gracias a Dios." Even aspirin and anti-acid medicine are extra expenses that are hard to fit into the family's limited budget.

Written by Nancy Lewis and Randy Fay, Kiva fellows

loans.use: To purchase stock for her store and yarn for weaving

loans.name: Edgar

texts.es:
Edgar is 23 years old. He is single and lives with his parents. His father is a policeman and his mother a teacher; he inherited the business from his father. Thanks to his grocery store, today he is doing the 3rd year of college at the faculty of philosophy. He has a sister who is 17 years old and helps him in the business.

He has been managing the business since five years ago. The business is well located since there aren't many other similar businesses in the area. He needs the credit to buy products such as sugar, flour, rice, noodles, bread and others.

Translated from Spanish by Luis López Martinelli, Kiva Volunteer.


Edgar tiene 23 años, es soltero vive con sus padres, su padre es policía y su madre docente; heredó el negocio de su padre. Gracias a la despensa, su negocio, hoy día ya está cursando el tercer año en la Facultad de Filosofía. Tiene una hermana de 17 años quien le ayuda en el negocio. Hace cinco años que administra el negocio el cual está bien ubicado debido a la poca cantidad de negocio existente en la zona Necesita el crédito para la compra de mercaderías como azúcar, harina, arroz, fideos, panificados y otros.

loans.use: Purchasing oil, sugar, noodles, flour and spices  / Compra de aceite, azúcar, fideos, harina, yerba.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase raw materials and new sewing machine for clothing business.

loans.name: Yesenía Carolina

texts.es:
Yesenía currently lives with a son in the Las Moritas suburb of Lurdes Colon. Her business began initially as a clothes store, but now she wants to continue this while increasing her stock of other products. She also wants to start selling typical food, for which she needs to buy a kitchen grill in order to make these typical dishes and to have another source of income for her family.

Translated from the Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

Actualmente vive con un hijo en Colonia Las Morítas de Lourdes Colón. Su negocio inicialmente lo comenzó con venta de ropa, actualmente lo mantiene y quiere incrementarlo surtiendola con más producto. Tambien quiere iniciar la venta de comida Típica, para lo cual necesita comprar una "cocina plancha" para elaborar estos platos típicos y tener otra fuente de ingreso para su familia.

loans.use: Increase merchandise

location.town: Lourdes Colón, departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Vicente

texts.en:
Vincente B. is a 38-year-old man who is married to twenty-six-year-old Mercedes Ruiz. They have two young school- age children. Since his childhood, Mr. B. has sacrificed much to help his grandfather as a butcher in their meat shop. However, after his grandfather passed away five years ago, Vincente was left in charge of the family business and had to secure labor for the butcher shop.

Today the meat shop is still a great success, however, Mr. B. is asking for a loan to help the operation grow and become even more profitable. With a loan he will buy more cattle to raise and sell in his butcher shop.

loans.use: To  purchase animals to fatten for his butcher shop

loans.name: Wampala East A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Asha B.. She is currently in the business of used clothing sales and is requesting a loan to add to the business. Asha is 23 years old and is married. Her husband is a driver. She has 5 children ranging from age 3 months to 18 and most of her children go to school. Each week, Asha makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to start a retail shop. Asha has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Asha is joined in her small group by Betty N., Zillah K., Irene N., and Betty K.. Betty N. has a business running a retail shop and wants to increase stock. Zillah K. is currently operating a business selling used clothes and wants a loan to add capital. Irene N. operates a retail shop business and wants to boost business. Betty K. is currently in the business of selling maize and is requesting a loan to purchase more maize from the villages.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell and to expand business

loans.name: Magaly

texts.es:
Magali is a young mother who works hard every day to give her daughter the best. Along with her husband, Magali has worked for the last two years making tiles and bricks. Her products are of such high quality that in record time she has become one the best brick and tile makers in her area. Magali wants to be able to educate her daughter, who is now 3, and is therefore seeking a loan to purchase supplies for tile making. Please consider helping Magali so that she can continue to make progress in her work.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Chegezy, Kiva volunteer.

Magali es una joven madre que se esfuerza cada día para ofrecer a su única niña lo mejor de su trabajo, ella y su esposo decidieron hace 2 años dedicarse de manera independiente a la fabricación de tejas y ladrillos, la calidad de sus productos ha hecho que en tiempo récord se convierta en una de las fábricas más sobresalientes de su zona, el deseo de Magali es poder educar a su niña que ahora tiene 3 años, solicita un préstamo para invertirlos en la compra de insumos para la fabricación de tejas. Apoya a Magali a continuar y alcanzar el progreso.

loans.use: Purchase of supplies to make tiles

loans.name: Mwanshasha's Group

texts.en:
Mwanshasha is married with 4 children, ages 15 to 26. Mwanshasha owns a small food vending store, which she started in 2007. Every day she works from 6:30 AM to 8:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Bituni, who has a business dealing in fish sales.

loans.use: To buy more food items (Irish potatoes, rice, flour, etc) for her business

loans.name: Susan Kimbugwe's Group

texts.en: Susan is a leader of 4 members. She is 29 years old and is married with 4 children, who are 9, 6, 4 and 2 years old. Three are in school. She lives within a semi-urban community within a slum. She has operated a salon for 4 years, and the main challenge she faces is stiff competition. Her business has provided her with a motorcycle for public transport and the ability to pay school dues. She intends to stock hair oils and weaves to reduce the negative effect of rising prices, and would like to start rearing chickens to supplement her current income. Susan has successfully paid back 5 loans.

loans.use: To stock hair oils and weaves, and start rearing chickens.

loans.name: Sophoin

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophoin N., 28, and her husband, Mr. Sinat Ny, 32, live across Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 2002 and have three sons (shown in the picture).

Mrs. Sophoin has been a silk weaver for five years. This is a skill that she learned from her neighbor. She sells her finished products to a man in the village, who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh. Mr. Sinat has been a fisherman for eight years. He fishes from a river and lake near the village and sells the fish to villagers. His boat is old and broken. He needs money to purchase a new boat and fishing net.

Mrs. Sophoin is requesting a loan of $400 to purchase one boat and fishing net for her husband.

loans.use: To purchase one boat and fishing net .

loans.name: Julio Del Carmen

texts.es:
At 70 years old Julio likes to work as though he were 20. He is a brick layer and works independently on construction projects. He is single and has three children, aged 12, 20 and 30. He has one adolescent left to educate and it is for that child that Julio puts in so much effort at work every day. He wants to give a dignified home to his son and his life partner, who takes on the responsibility of caring for the home. With the loan he will replace a part of his roof that is in poor condition. AFODENIC considers Julio an excellent client.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Don Julio a la edad de 70 años le gusta trabajar como si tuviera 20, es albañil y hacer trabajos de construcción de forma independiente. Es soltero y tiene 3 hijos de 12, 20 y 30 años. Todavía le queda un adolescente por terminar de educar, y es por él por quien don Julio se esfuerza dia a dia en su trabajo. Desea darle una vivienda digna a su hijo y su compañera de vida quien se encarga del cuido del hogar. Con el préstmo cambiará parte del techo de su vivienda que está en mal estado. Don Julio es un exelente cliente para AFODENIC

loans.use: Install a new roof on his house.

loans.name: Anor

texts.ru:
Anor D. lives in the Fayzabad region. She is 42 years old and has 5 children. She has a high school education. Anor has a small store at the center of the area. She purchases products from wholesale suppliers and resells them at retail prices. This business allows her to support her large family. Today, Anor would like to increase the product assortment at her store, which requires money. She has decided to take out an 18 month loan for this purpose.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Давлатова Анор жительница района Файзобод . Возраст 42 года, женат,имеет 5 детей. Образование среднее. Клиентка имеет небольшой магазин в центре района.Она покупает товар у оптовых поставщиков и реализует его в розницу. Этот вид деятельности позволяет ей содержать свою большую семью. В данный момент клиентка хочет увеличить асссортимент своего магазина. Для чего ей нужны деньги.Она решила взять кредит сроком на 18 месяцев.

loans.use: Increase product assortment

loans.name: Rene

texts.es: Rene G. es casado, tiene dos hijos de 4 y 2 años respectivamente. La familia  vive en la calle Sucre de la zona Rio seco en la ciudad de El Alto. Rene es conductor de minibús y también se dedica a la carpintería. Solicita crédito para comprar repuestos para su vehículo. Es su primer crédito en Impro y nuestras evaluaciones indican que puede recibir su ayuda.
texts.en:
Rene G. is married and has two sons, who are 4 and 2 years of age respectively. The family lives on Sucre Street in the Rio Seco neighborhood in the city of El Alto. Rene is a mini-bus driver and also works in carpentry. He is applying for a loan to purchase parts for his vehicle. It is his first credit in Impro and our evaluations indicate that he can receive your help.

Translated from Spanish by Aimee Sostowski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Mini-Bus Maintenance

loans.name: Soulemane

texts.fr: Soulemane W. est âgé de 31 ans, marié et père d’un enfant. Il est conducteur de taxi moto à Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Il détient jusque là la moto d’une autre personne et souhaite par ce crédit, le premier à FECECAV, acheter sa propre moto. Avec cette nouvelle moto, Soulemane espère faire plus de profits pour subvenir aux besoins de sa famille
texts.en:
Soulemane W., age 31, is married and the father of one child. He drives a motorcycle taxi in Lomé, the capital of Togo. Until now, he's been using another person's motorcycle, and he wishes to use this first loan with FECECAV to buy his own motorcycle. With this new motorcycle, Soulemane hopes to increase its profit to provide for its family needs.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Im

texts.en:
Mrs. Im Thol, 40, and her husband, Mr. Sothy Seng, 42, live along National Road Number One about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They married in 1987 and have four children, two sons and two daughters. Three of them study at the local school and the eldest works in a garment factory.

Im and her husband have been growing vegetables for twenty years. They grow many kinds of vegetables and crops on their farmland near their house.  They sell these vegetables to a middleman in the village. Besides farming, the couple also sells firewood.  Im is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticides for farming.  She will also purchase a firewood cutting machine.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizer, pesticides and a firewood cutting machine.

loans.name: Chrek

texts.en:
Mrs. Chrek T., the 38-year-old mother of four children, two of whom are garment workers while another works in construction, lives in Treal Commune, Kompong Tom Province with her 42-year- old husband, Mr. Thoeun Ket. The couple earns a living by selling vegetables such as cabbages, water lilies, and morning glory that they have purchased wholesale.

Chrek is now requesting a $500 loan to buy additional vegetables to sell and a trailer to use with their motorcycle for more efficient transportation of produce .

loans.use: To buy a trailer and more vegetables.

loans.name: Vuong Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Vương Thị Vân năm nay 47 tuổi, chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2006.   Hiện nay cả hai vợ chồng chị đều tham gia kinh doanh buôn bán và gia đình chị đang có một của hàng kinh doanh hàng tạp hóa, bánh kẹo... tại huyện Nghi Lộc tỉnh Nghệ An. Công việc kinh doanh cũng là công việc đem lại nguồn thu chủ yếu của gia đình chị Vân với mức thu nhập 3.000.000đ/ tháng.
Vòng vốn tới chị Vân mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư vốn cho công việc kinh doanh hàng tạp hoá.
texts.en:
Mrs. Vương Thị Vân, 47 years old, has participated in the TYM Fund since 2006. Currently, she and her husband both work in their shop selling groceries and snacks in Nghi Lộc district, Nghệ An province. This business provides Mrs. Vân and her family with an income of about 3,000,000 VND (183 USD) per month. In the next lending cycle, Mrs. Vân hopes to borrow 9,000,000 VND (550 USD) to invest in her grocery store.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Grocery shop

loans.name: Mujeres Valientes Group

texts.en:
Jesula E. is a coordinator for Mujeres Valientes (Brave Women), of the Bank of Hope. Thirty women belong to Mujeres Valientes, and 20 of them have successfully repaid previous loans. Jesula's group has ten women. The loan will be shared among the members of the group, who run various businesses.

Jesula is 29 years old; her husband is 30. They have two girls, 11 and 12 years old. Jesula runs a business selling clothes and shoes. She usually buys her merchandise in Santiago and resells for a profit in Cabarete, which is a tourist destination. Her customers are from Haiti and the Dominican Republic. She does not sell to tourists because because she does not speak English. 

Jesula has repaid two loans from Esperanza. This will be her third loan. These loans made it possible for Jesula to start her business. She used her first loan to stock clothing. With the second loan, she branched out into shoes and expanded her clothing inventory. She plans to use the third loan to diversify her business further by stocking perfume and soap as well. 

In her spare time Jesula likes to read the Bible, and also books on child rearing and running a household. Her dream is to have her own shop in the center of Cabarete, where she could attract the tourist trade. Today she lives in a rented house, and she hopes that one day she will be able to buy her own house. She also hopes that her children will have an opportunity to study at the university.

loans.use: To buy perfume and soap for resale

loans.name: Angela Teresa

texts.es:
ANGELA TERESA, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Triunfadoras” ubicado en la Av. Alfonso Ugarte Mz. 278 – Distrito de Callería, tiene 53 años de edad, 03 hijos , socia   de Manuela Ramos 09 años.

El primer préstamo que recibió fue de S/. 300.00, compro carne roja (res), vísceras (mondongos, lengua, riñón, etc.); en poca cantidad, obtuvo un puesto en el mercado N° 02 de la ciudad de Pucallpa, la razón de vender fue el fallecimiento de su esposo, busco la manera de trabajar para cumplir con el sustento familiar con el apoyo de sus hijos.
Con este préstamo de S/. 1000 Nuevos Soles compró carne roja en cantidad, vísceras, su venta  aumenta  de igual manera los clientes, para mantener su carne fresca compró un congelador de gran ayuda para ella, trabaja en conjunto con sus hijos. 

Esta muy contenta por el gran apoyo que le brindo y le brinda Manuela Ramos en los momentos que mas a necesitado.
texts.en:
ANGELA TERESA belongs to the Communal Bank called “Las Triunfadoras” located on Av. Alfonso Ugarte 278 – District of Callería. She is 53 years old, and she has 3 children. She has been a partner of Manuela Ramos for 9 years. With first loan of 300.00 Nuevos Soles ($90) she bought meat (beef), and guts (tripes, tongue kidney, etc.); in small quantities. She obtained a stand in the market N ° 02 of the city of Pucallpa.The reason for working selling meat is the death of her husband. She looked for a way of working to meet with the family needs with the help and support of her children. With this loan of 1000.00 Nuevos Soles ($325) she bought meat and guts in bigger quantity, her sales increased the same way as her clients. In order to keep her the meat fresh, she bought a freezer that has been of great help for her. She works as a team with her children. She is very happy for the support that Manuela Ramos (Kiva's partner) is giving her at the moments she needs it most.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy meat and guts in bigger quantities and a freezer to keep the meat.

loans.name: Abdo

texts.en:
Abdo is a 45-year-old man who lives in Bekaa with his wife and their four children. Abdo has been working as a florist for two years. He requests a loan of $1,000 in order to purchase flowers for his business. This is the first time that Abdo has requested a loan.

Abdo is special in his work because he does nice flower arrangements and he is good at his work. His clients can be anybody from his region. When he first started his business, he didn’t have the start-up capital. Abdo decided on doing his business because of his experience. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase flowers

loans.name: Olga

texts.es:
Olga es socia del Bancomunal Amigas Unidas.
Olga es casada tiene 46 años, tiene 46 años, un hijo de 23 años, que estudia.
Olga tiene su tienda hace ocho años, empezó vendiendo ternos hechos pero hace dos años contrato dos sastres para que confecciones a medida a sus clientes, su tienda se llama “sastrería  Ángelo”
Olga necesita un crédito de 3600 soles, para la copra de ternos hechos, telas para  confeccionar, y accesorios.  
Desde que está en Finca se ha podido comprar sus maquinas industriales, gracias a las inversiones realizadas.  
El sueño de Olga es tener un taller de confecciones grande en gamarra.
texts.en:
Olga is a member of the Amigas Unidas Communal Bank. She is 46 years of age and married with a son, 23, who is a student. Olga has had her store, Sastrería Ángelo, for eight years. She began selling manufactured suits, but two years ago hired two tailors to produce suits made-to-order for her clients. Olga needs a loan of 3,600 Sols to purchase ready-made suits, fabrics for custom suits and accessories. Since she has been working with FINCA Peru, she has been able to buy production machinery thanks to the loans she has received. Olga's dream is to have a large tailor shop in Gamarra.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase suits, fabrics and accessories.

loans.name: Trinh Thi

texts.en:
P. Trịnh (1716080889) is a 56-year-old woman living in the town of Thanh Hoá. She is married and has six adult children. To make a living, P. owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. The main source of income from the business comes from raising pigs for sale. P. has been engaged in this business for over 30 years and earns approximately 2500000 dong a month from these activities.

In 2008, P. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. P. is now requesting a loan of 9000000 dong which will be used to purchase breeding livestock. This loan will be the second loan taken out by the borrower from TYM Fund. P. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase breeder pigs

loans.name: Rana

texts.en:
Rana is thirty-two years old and lives in Tyre, in southern Lebanon. Rana owns a costume jewelry and accessory shop. She sells costume jewelry, belts, make up, beauty products, hats and a lot more. She requested a loan from the Kiva field partner, Al Majmoua, in order to purchase merchandise for her shop. This is the first time that Rana has requested a loan. 
Rana is recognized for her work because she offers a big variety of items and knows how to treat her clients, who are people from her region. Since she first started her business, she has been successful. Rana decided to open her business because she wanted to have independent work. In the future, she plans to increase her business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her shop.

loans.name: Yvette

texts.fr:
M. Yvette est née en 1957 à Guézin. Yvette  est veuve et mère d’une fille. Yvette vit à Irédé, un quartier de la Commune de Cotonou, Capitale Économique du Bénin. Avant la mort de son mari, Yvette vendait les produits vivriers. Mais depuis dix (10) ans, Yvette vend des  tissus et de l’huile de palme. C’est de façon ambulante que Yvette vend ses produits. Yvette se promène de quartier en quartier pour proposer ses produits. C’est à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin que Yvette achète ses produits. Yvette a déjà eu un crédit à ALIDé pour renforcer son fonds de commerce. Yvette a bien remboursé ce crédit. Yvette demande aujourd’hui un deuxième prêt pour mieux développer son activité. 

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500.
texts.en:
M. Yvette was born in 1957 in Guézin. She is a widow and the mother of a girl. She lives in Irédé, a district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Before her husband’s death, Yvette used to sell staple goods. But for ten years, she has been selling cloth and palm oil. She is an itinerant seller, walking from district to district to offer her goods. There, in Dantokpa, the grand international market of Benin, she acquires her merchandise. She has already had an Alidé loan. She’s now asking for a second loan to develop her business further. Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 7 bolts of Hitarget cloth (12 meters each) and 50 liters of palm oil

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida, age 49, is married to Reynaldo A.. Her family lives in Barangay Tandul Cabatuan, Isabela. They have four children: Rosemire, Renalyn, Girlie Mae, and their youngest, Kracean Felle, who still attends high school. One of the children is now married and the two others are working to help support the family. Zenaida finds ongoing strength in her belief that “before fear holds you back, go forward with faith, to make you a better person.”

She has been managing a store for almost two years now in their rural village. She is earning a weekly income of PHP 500 that benefits her family directly, especially her children. She wants to purchase more grocery items for her retailing business so as to have a better profit, but, since she doesn’t have enough capital to buy these items, Zenaida is therefore requesting a loan from ASKI, a microfinance partner of Kiva in the Philippines. The loan would amount to PHP 10,000 and would be used as additional working capital.

She hopes to make her business grow so that she can increase the support she offers her family.

loans.use: To obtain business capital for her grocery store business

loans.name: Rosmonde

texts.fr: G. Rosmonde est née le 14 Mars 1966 à Décamè dans le Département du Zou. Rosmonde est mariée et est mère de cinq enfants. Sur les cinq enfants de Rosmonde, trois sont encore à sa charge et sont tous scolarisés. Rosmonde réside avec sa famille au quartier pk10 sur la route de Porto-Novo, Capitale Administrative et Politique de la République du BENIN. Rosmonde vend des divers (Bonbons, biscuits, boîtes de lait, de sardines, de tomates, de sucres, les pâtes alimentaires, les savons de lessive, de vaisselle et de toilette, piles, bougies, etc.), des fruits et des boissons de brasserie. Rosmonde a déjà bénéficié de trois crédits de ALIDé; et Rosmonde rembourse ses crédits toujours sans aucune difficulté. Pour renforcer son activité et satisfaire davantage ses clients, Rosmonde sollicite un quatrième crédit de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Rosmonde G. was born on the March 14th, 1966 in Décamè in the County of Zou. Rosmonde is married and is the mother of five children. Of Rosmonde's five children, three are still in her care and all are students. Rosmonde lives with her family in the neighborhood of PK10 on the road of Porto-Novo, the administrative and political capital of the Republic of Benin.

Rosmonde sells a variety of products - candies, cookies, cartons of milk, sardines, tomatoes, sugar, pasta, dish-washing soap, bath soap, batteries, candles, fruits, drinks etc. Rosmonde has already been the beneficiary of three loans by ALIDé and Rosmonde has always repaid the loans without difficulty. To reinforce her activities and satisfy more customers, Rosmonde is requesting a forth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy ten, six-bottle cases of sugared drinks; four cases of apples and five cases of cookies.

loans.name: Yackeline Karen

texts.es:
Yackeline, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Totoritas”  que esta ubicado en la Comunidad de Chimu, el distrito de Puno, Provincia de Puno, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 18 años de edad, de estado civil soltera, no tiene hijos. Esta estudiando Educación superior y vive  en la Comunidad de Chimu Central. 

Es socia nueva, y requiere un préstamo de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles para iniciar su negocio de venta de artesanías en totora (planta de la zona), así ella podrá ayudarse en sus estudios.

Su deseo es poder culminar sus estudios y así poder también ayudar en su casa.
A ella le gustan las facilidades en los préstamos y la confraternidad que hay en el Banco Comunal.
texts.en:
Yackeline is a member of the Community Bank "Las Totoritas" located in the Chimu community, Puno district, Puno province and department. She is 18 years old, single and without children. She is studying for an advanced degree and lives in the Community of Chimu Central. She is a new member and is in need of a loan of 500 New Soles to start her business of selling crafts made from totora (a reed that grows in the area), and this way she will be able to help finance her studies. Her wishes are to be able to finish her studies and also help in her home. She likes the easiness of the loan process and the fellowship that exists at the Community Bank.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of materials to make mats (quesanas)

loans.name: Nuevo Horizonte Group

texts.es: Las Cuatro señoras y su hija de doña Catarina que se muestra en la foto, es el grupo Nuevo Horizonte, que a venido a pedir un apoyo para ellas, ya que quieren ampliar sus capitales  para tener mojor ingresos y tener mojor condiciones de vida; ellas elaboran y fabrican ropa tipica y compra y venta de la misma, para poder sobre salir de esas condiciones que se encuentra  y las tres alquilan y una no, y quieren aumentar sus capital y asi obtener màs imgresos para poder posteriormente construir una pequeña vivienda, para hacer de su realidad de sus sueños, ellas acuden a la Asociaciòn ASDIR para concretizar este sueño; ya que otras entidades no les apoyan por estar en el area de Pobleza.
texts.en:
The four women and Mrs. Catarina’s daughter, who are shown in the photo, are members of New Horizon (Nuevo Horizonte) Group. They are asking for support, since they want to increase their capital so that they can have higher incomes and improve the quality of their lives. They make, buy and sell typical clothing, so that they can survive in the conditions in which they find themselves. Three of them rent a home and one does not. They want to increase their capital and, in this way, have a larger income so that they can later build a small home to make their dreams comes true. They came to Asociación ASDIR to realize their dream, since other entities didn’t support them because they are from a poor area.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Capital for their businesses

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah owns a small tailoring shop in Kayole. A mother of three, Hannah aspires to grow her business and become a fabric wholesaler. She has requested her first loan of Ksh. 20,000 in order to add to her stock of materials. Hannah dreams of educating her children to the highest level.  She describes herself as patient and hard-working.



Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable micro-finance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: Add to her stock of materials

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora H. makes snacks and delicacies and peddles them in her community. She is 34 years old, married and has three school-age children. They are from the village of Kibogsod, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. Nora has been in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month.

In August 2009, Nora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nora is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase products to sell. This will be Nora's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to supplement the income of her family and support the education of her children.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria M. is 31 years old and is married with six children aged between 13 and 2. She also looks after three dependents.

Gloria has been in the business of selling loincloths for five years, working eleven hours a day and creating jobs for two employees. After realizing that her investment is too low to earn more profit, she is now requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through purchasing more loincloths.

By using this loan, Gloria hopes, with the profit she will get, to help her husband to build their own house and pay school fees for their children.

loans.use: To buy more loincloths

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a 43 year old mother of five who sells new clothes. She has been in this business for two years and hopes to be a role model in business in her area. She is requesting a loan of Kes. 40,000 to add stock of clothes to her business. She hopes to educate her children and have a prosperous family. She describes herself as positive.

About Faulu Kenya:
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To add stock of clothes to her shop.

loans.name: Issa

texts.en: Issa S. is a 28-year-old. He and his wife are business-people. They have three children. For six years, Issa has owned a market stall. He is now seeking a loan of 1 million Leones from SMT and Kiva lenders to invest in his rice-selling business.

loans.use: Expansion of business

loans.name: Bonalyn

texts.en:
Bonalyn is already 25 years old and is married to Alexander who is a tricycle driver within their village of Quezon, San Isidro. They are gifted with a daughter named Shane who is four years old now.

Bonalyn is a retailer of electronic cellphone loads and at the same time she is a dealer of cosmetics products. She would like to purchase all the orders of her customers but she lacks capital. That’s the reason why she would like to borrow additional capital of PHP 5,000 from Kiva lenders. The amount that she is requesting will be utilized in buying products and some of this amount will be used in her electronic cellphone loading business.

Bonalyn is praying that her business will become profitable and productive.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Georges

texts.fr: D. Georges est né en 1978 à Ekpè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Georges est marié et père de deux enfants qui sont scolarisés. Georges a un autre enfant à sa charge. Georges réside avec ses enfants et sa femme, à Ekpè depuis 8 ans. La femme de Georges l'aide à supporter les charges de la famille. Georges a arrêté les classes au cours secondaire. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants, Georges mène comme activité, la vente de cartes de recharges téléphonique dans sa boutique à Ekpè. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et aussi à Ekpè, que Georges s'approvisionne. Georges a déjà obtenu une fois de crédit à ALIDé et l'a bien remboursé. Dans l'optique d'augmenter son fonds de roulement et de renforcer son activité, Georges sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Georges D. was born in 1978 in Ekpè, in the town of Sèmè-Podji in Benin. Georges is married and is the father of two children who are in school. Georges also has one other child in his care. Georges has lived with his children and wife in Ekpè for 8 years. Georges' wife helps him in providing for the family. Georges ended his education in secondary school. To meet his needs and those of his children, Georges runs a business selling rechargeable phone cards in his store in Ekpè. It is at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin, and also in Ekpè, that Georges gets his supplies. Georges has already obtained one loan through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners), which he repaid properly. With the goal of increasing his working capital and strengthening his business, Georges is seeking a second loan through ALIDÉ.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rechargeable phone cards

loans.name: Sugey Del Socorro

texts.es: Doña Sugey es una mujer con mucho deseo de poder terminar su casa ya que aun le falta mucho por hacer, es por eso trabaja para poder apoyar  a su esposo con los gastos básicos del hogar como: pago de agua, luz  y para poder dar lo necesario para los estudios de sus tres hijos los cuales están cursando su primaria. Desde hace varios años trabaja como foreadora en una institución de los chinos. Pero en los últimos meses todo ha cambiado y teme que cierren la empresa debido ala situación socioeconómica  del país. Pues con cada gobierno hay políticas diferentes. La iniciativa del préstamo es por que con su salario y el de su esposo no ajusta para poder comprar todo el material para hacer un corredor en frente de la casa es por eso recurre a la institución para obtener el financiamiento y poder comenzar a construir para una mejor higiene del polvo como para un mejor bien para su familia. Para esto comprara piedra, arena, cemento y comenzar la obra, el cual esta contenta por poder tener la oportunidad de ser sujeta al crédito ya que por el plazo y el bajo interés de pago gozara de mejoras a corto plazo.
texts.en:
Mrs. Sugey is a woman who wants to finish building her house, and she still has a lot of work to do. So she works to help her husband with the basic household costs like the electric bill, the water bill, and study materials for their three children who are in primary school. For several years she has worked for a Chinese company, but in the last few months everything has changed. She worries that they will close the plant because of the economic situation in the country. The reason she wants a loan is because her salary and that of her husband are not enough to be able to buy the material to build a sidewalk in front of their house. With the loan she could begin to build the walk, which will be cleaner and more hiegenic for her family. She will buy stone, sand, and cement to complete the work. She is happy for the opportunity to receive a loan because the payment schedule and the low interest will help her make home improvements in the short term.

Translated from Spanish by Patrick King, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of materials to build a walkway

loans.name: Joyce Mwelu

texts.en: Joyce sells secondhand clothes, such as skirts and T-shirts, to frequent customers and passers-by in the open-air Gikomba Market. She started this business six months ago after quitting her previous employment.   She has two employees.  Her business faces a challenge when rainy season arrives as her business is outdoors.  She will be using the requested loan of KES20,000 to buy a kiosk and restock clothes.  In the future, she wants to be a wholesaler.   Joyce is married and has a four year old daughter.  She describes herself as social, honest and trustworthy.

loans.use: To add more stock of clothes, shoes and buy a kiosk where she will be operating from.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.es:
La señora Nancy, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Abejitas”, Distrito de Moyobamba, Provincia de Moyobamba, Departamento de San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 39 años y es madre de 03 hijos, que aun dependen de ella.

Nancy, lleva varios años dedicándose a la confección de vestidos, poco a poco fue generando sus propios ingresos y ahorrando su dinero, queriendo así implementar su taller de confección de vestidos y como tenia la habilidad  para la costura, no dudo en hacerlo y con el apoyo del Movimiento Manuela Ramos, decidió implementar su propio negocio ubicado en su misma casa.

Nos cuenta que le va muy en sus costuras, trabaja con pedidos que con anticipación sus clientes le solicitan. A quienes les  atiende  con la amabilidad y el carisma  que le caracteriza. 

Con este préstamo de S/. 1300.00, comprará telas en metros, de diferentes especies y colores, instrumentos que utiliza como tijeras, hilos en carretes grande y de variados colores, agujas de coser y de maquina, alfileres, botones. 

Nancy, hoy en día se siente una mujer muy realizada, con más ganas de alcanzar y hacer realidad sus demás sueños. Agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudarla a iniciar su negocio y también a muchas mujeres que  quieren crecer empresarialmente.
texts.en:
Nancy belongs to the “Las Abejitas” Communal Bank, in the Moyobamba district of Moyobamba province, Department of San Martin, Peru. She is 39 years old and married, and has 3 children who still depend on her. For many years Nancy has been working as a dressmaker. Bit by bit she generated her own income and saved her money, as she wanted to set up her own dressmaking shop. Since she had good sewing skills she was confident in doing this, and with the help of the Manuela Ramos movement she decided to set up her own business, located in her home. She tells us the her dressmaking work is going well. She works completing orders that her customers have made in advance. She attends to them with her characteristic charisma and good nature. With this loan of 1300 Peruvian soles, she will buy fabrics by the meter, of different types and colors, and also instruments for cutting, large spools of thread in various colors, sewing needles, pins, and buttons. Today Nancy feels like a very fulfilled woman, with the desire to achieve and make real the rest of her dreams. She thanks the Manuela Ramos movement for helping her start her business and for helping many women who want to grow in their business skills.

Translated from Spanish by Catherine Fountain, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy materials for sewing

loans.name: The Women’S Bank United For A Better Tomorrow (1) Group

texts.en:
The official name of this group translates as “The Women’s Bank United for a Better Tomorrow”. This will be the group’s second loan from Fundacion Mujer. The first was for 100,000 colones for each group member, and was paid back on time and in full. The members of this group live in Coto Brus, Puntarenas, a rural community located in the southern region of Costa Rica near the Panamanian border.

These women are in the business of animal rearing. They work with cows, pigs and chickens. This loan will be used for the purchase of animals as well as general investments in activities conducive to the healthy upbringing of animal livestock such as food, shelter and nutrients.

Cows, pigs and chickens are raised by the women until they are ready to be sold. Chickens are generally sold in the community, to neighbors, friends and acquaintances, whereas pigs and cows are sold to purchasers who travel to the community from nearby cities. These purchasers can be middlemen/women who will resell the pigs or cows to butchers for final use. The purchasers may also be the butchers themselves.

The group members’ families benefit greatly from their livestock businesses. In general, the women have the goal of rendering the earnings generated through their sales more stable by acquiring more livestock and seeking out new clients. An obstacle for the group has been the unpredictable effects of animals becoming sick. Changes in climate have affected the quality and quantity of grazing land for cows as well as the susceptibility of chickens and pigs to disease.

Jennifer P. A. is the 21-year-old mother of two who lives in Coto Brus. She had her first child when she was sixteen years old. She has a business rearing and selling pigs which she started with an initial investment of 100,000 colons. Jennifer appreciates the importance of providing a quality product to her clients in order to keep them coming back to her instead of choosing another producer. The values she expects her group to display are responsibility, solidarity and honesty.

Maritza G. P. is a 32 year old woman who lives in Coto Brus with her husband of sixteen years and their four children. She has a business rearing and selling cows. Maritza says she wants her business to grow in order to improve her quality of life and that of her family. She comments that before she was approved for her loan she was afraid; with the loan, she feels secure.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Anene

texts.en:
Anene sells sarongs, hair gear and bags in her retail shop. She is married with four children who are in primary and secondary schools. Her husband is a civil servant and he also supports the home. They live in Lagos State. 

With over 14 years of experience in sales, Anene is very willing to expand her business. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. She is very concerned about the growth of her business and the upkeep of her family. She hopes for a loan of 100,000 nairas to purchase more sarongs and bags to sell. She has a good relationship with LAPO. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and bags to sell

loans.name: Ann

texts.en: Ann W. M. is 29 years old. She is married to a businessman and they have a one-year-old child. Ann runs a beauty salon located in the Central Business District of Nairobi, Kenya's capital. This business is profitable and the only major challenge she faces is that there are many people in the area doing the same kind of work, which gives customers many choices. She also has to work very hard to ensure the success of her salon. Ann has applied for a loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more supplies and equipment to use in her business. In future, she hopes to open a spa and provide other services such as massage. She also hopes to open more salons. She is a beautiful, hardworking and humble woman.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her beauty salon

loans.name: Chheng

texts.en: Mrs. C. is 50 years of age. Her husband died of senility many years ago. She has earnest financial partners in her two daughters, who help support the family by working in a garment factory. In order to generate a daily income, Mrs. C. sells chickens that she buys from her wholesale supplier, earning about $3 each day. Recently, Mrs. C. received many orders from her customers who need a lot of chickens for their ceremony parties. Mrs. C. does not have an adequate supply of chickens for her customers. She is asking for a loan to buy more chickens, in order to better satisfy the needs of her customers.

loans.use: To buy more chickens to sell.

loans.name: Bahit

texts.en:
Bahit is 36 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Bayan-Ulgiy province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent.  His two children, ages 14 and 10, attend a local secondary school. Bahit operates a clothing business in his town with the help of his wife. He sells a variety of clothes to many customers. 

Bahit has been operating his business since 2003, and has steadily expanded his business. During the summer, Bahit and his wife, Janargul, sell their products in two places, but during the winter they sell together in one place. They purchase their products from Ereen, a Chinese border town, and sell them to their customers. Since they have started the business, their quality of life has been improving. 

Bahit is a very hardworking person and he is focused on the future. He says, “I would like to purchase a car after my children grow up and graduate from the university.”

He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more inventory from Ereen to resell them for a profit

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Margarita Bonitas 2 Group

texts.es: El grupo “Margaritas Bonitas 2” esta representada por la señora Ubaldina y conformada por 10 miembros residentes del mismo barrio caracterizado por ser personas muy responsables, honestas, trabajadoras y muy capaces a pesar D. sus bajos recursos como lo demuestra la señora Ubaldina que es viuda y madre D. cuatro hijos a los cuales a sacado adelante a pesar D. no tener el apoyo D. su esposo que ya la dejo hace mucho tiempo, ella se dedica a la venta D. comida en una pensión en la que venD. almuerzo familiar y los fines D. semana platos D. la tarD., ella vive en la casa D. su hija mayor que también es miembro del grupo pero con otro tipo D. negocio, ella desea poder tener una pensión mas amplia ya que sus clientes se han incrementado y no tiene un buen lugar donD. recibirlos es por esta razón que requiere del crédito para poder ampliar y mejorar su pensión y darles a sus clientes una mejor atención. El resto D. las socias tienen negocios varios como lechería, venta D. quesillo, repostería, atención D. local en la zona D. linD., carpintería, venta D. ropa americana, venta D. tripitas y la venta D. pollo. La competencia existe en sus negocios pero los socios saben como salir adelante gracias a su experiencia y ganas D. salir adelante para poder darles a sus familias una mejor calidad D. vida. El préstamo actual es para el incremento D. mercadería para agrandar sus negocios. El grupo va cursando un segundo ciclo con la institución por lo que saben como manejar los fondos y salir adelante para mejor cada día más.
texts.en:
The "Pretty Daisies 2" group is represented by Mrs. Ubaldina and maD. up of 10 members who are residents of the same neighborhood and considered to be very responsible, honest, hard-working, and capable despite their lack of resources, as shown by Mrs. Ubaldina, who is a widow and the mother of 4 children, whom she has helped get ahead despite not having the support of her husband who left her a long time ago. She works selling food in a boarding house. During the week she sells a basic lunch and on the weekends sells meals in the afternoon. She lives in her oldest daughter's house, who is also a member of the group, but who works in a different type of business. She desires to be able to have a larger boarding house, as her customers have grown in number and she does not have enough room to take them in. For this reason she needs the loan to be able to expand and improve the boarding house and proviD. her customers with better service. The rest of the members work with milk, cheese sales, pastries, carpentry, clothing sales, tripe sales, and chicken sales. They face competition in their businesses, but the members know how to get ahead thanks to their experience and will to succeed to proviD. their families with a better quality of life. The current loan is for increasing supply of merchandise and enlarging their businesses. The group is completing their second loan cycle with the institution and knows how to manage funds and continue to improve each day.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Meinecke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supplies

loans.name: Belen

texts.en:
Belen is an entrepreneur who does business in rice and pig farming. She manages a rice field and a piggery. She said that her business is going well because of the help of Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She’s been a member of CEVI since 2008. 

She is currently asking for a loan of 15,000 Philippine Pesos to continually support her business. She supports 7 children in her family. She is determined to do her best in providing for the needs of her family.

loans.use: farm supplies and pig feed

loans.name: Ferney

texts.es:
Después de ser empleado de una vidriería, Ferney López O. acudiendo a su espíritu independiente,  empezó su gran sueño hace 4 años con un local en el barrio Alquería la fragua en la Ciudad de Bogotá: montó  en sociedad  un negocio dedicado a la  fabricación de  divisiones para baños, el cual se disolvió y 6 meses  después inició su gran reto en un nuevo local en el barrio Kennedy, donde montó  “Vidrios el Rey” , una  vidriería donde fabrica  divisiones para baños y marquetería en general. La disolución de la sociedad fue su más grande desafío, porque perdió mucho dinero y se descapitalizó,  pero siguió ofreciendo sus servicios y ha logrado salir adelante. 
Este es su primer crédito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con el comprará  materia prima como vidrio, aluminio para marquetería y también lo usará en la  reparación de  su maquinaria   Sand Blast,  que consiste en un sistema de lanzamiento de materiales abrasivos con aire a presión, los cuales producen cambios sobre  superficies rígidas, como las que usa Ferney como sus principales materias primas: vidrio, mármol,  acrílico, madera y acero. Con este sistema podrá  optimizar resultados, lograr mayor uniformidad, abatir costos en mano de obra, minimizar tiempos de trabajo, mayor anclaje y adherencia de recubrimientos y conseguir mayor pureza del material con un mínimo de esfuerzo.
Su sueño es tener casa propia para disfrutarla con su cónyuge y sus dos hijos de 5 y 10 años de edad  y adquirir un vehículo para el transporte de mercancía para el negocio, porque hasta ahora alquila este servicio.
texts.en:
After having been employed at a glazier, Ferney López O. followed his dream to become independent and opened his own shop four years ago in Bogotá’s Alquería La Fragua neighborhood. He entered into a partnership and opened a business making shower enclosures; this lasted only six months. He then met a big challenge with a new locale in the Kennedy neighborhood called “Vidrios el Rey,” a glazier shop where he makes shower enclosures and general cabinetry. His greatest challenge was dissolving the partnership because he lost a lot of money and was decapitalized. But, he continued to offer his services and has managed to move ahead. This will be his 1st loan with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. He will use it to buy raw materials for cabinet making like, glass and aluminum; he will also use it to repair his sandblaster, which is equipment that shoots abrasive materials under pressure to bring about changes on rigid surfaces like the ones Ferney uses as his main raw ingredients: glass, marble, acrylic, wood and steel. With this equipment he will be able to optimize results, have more uniformity, lessen labor costs, minimize job completion time, insure better finish adherence and anchoring and attain more purity in the materials with a minimum of effort. His dream is to own his own house to enjoy with his wife and two children, who are 5 and 10 years of age, as well as to acquire a vehicle to transport merchandise for his business because to date he leases this service.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cabinet making raw materials like glass and aluminum; also to repair his sandblaster.

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora M. is from the village of San Rafael. She is 48 and married with one school-aged child. Leonora has a business selling ice cream to the local community. Leonora has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Leonora joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Leonora is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product line. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Leonora from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product line

loans.name: Mi

texts.en:
Mi P., 30, is married and lives with her husband and two children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for its Angkorean Temples.

P. produces traditional baskets to sell for an income of USD 4 per day. Her husband is a driver, earning an income of about USD 5 per day to help cover the family expenses.

P. is requesting a loan of USD 1,200 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to use to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband to use for commuting

loans.name: Johana

texts.en:
Johana Pavón, 21 years old, is single and lives with her parents in Conavi, a popular economic housing complex in Paraguay.  She has been dedicated to being a seamstress for more than 2 years, making comforters, bed sheets, drapes, upholstery, and much more.  She performs this activity with her mother, Ms. Ignacia Díaz.

To date, she has a large quantity of customers in the zones of Itá, San Lorenzo, Asunción, Fernando de la Mora, Lambaré, and several cities. As of now, Johana has an Overlock machine, a button machine, and a straightening machine, all of which she uses in her daily production.

She is asking for credit so she can buy another straightening machine because the one she has is very old and doesn’t work as well as it should.  She has said that with a new machine, she can increase her production in a considerable way.  She already has many orders and with the old machine, she would not be able to meet the demand of her work.
 
Johana is a very good worker and desires to continually to improve her situation.

loans.use: Buying a sewing machine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To provide a business (to purchase rice, beans, etc.)

loans.name: Mussarat's Group

texts.en:
Mussarat lives in a historic city of Pakistan called Multan. She is the mother of three daughters and a son. All of them are very young and attending school. Her husband is a salesman. He sells different kind of products in different areas and markets. 

She helps her husband financially by doing embroidery works. She has hired a worker who collects orders for her and she completes orders on time to earn a profit. She has been doing this work for over 18 years and has much experience in this field. She has also started selling bangles recently, which has started making her good profits also. 

She lives with her family in a small house of two rooms. She has minimized her expenses to survive financially but she wants her family to have a better standard of living. 

She has applied for a loan from Asasah for her embroidery business. With the loan amount, she will buy embroidery material in bulk that will help her to improve her business condition. She is a new loan user of Asasah and she hopes that this step will prove successful for her business. 

Note: In this photo, Mussarat is wearing the bangles in her group member Samina's hand.

loans.use: Purchase embroidery material for improving her embroidery business

loans.name: Fatima's Group

texts.en:
Fatima lives in a three room brick house in the small city of Chichawatni in south Punjab, Pakistan, famous for its agriculture industry. She is a 29-year-old housewife who also operates a sewing business from her home. She is very skilled at her craft and gets regular orders from her neighbors, charging them between 100-150 PKRs for each dress stitching. Fatima is the mother of three children who don’t yet go to school. She is married to U. M. who is involved in a bread-making and selling business in the market. He makes bread in an oven made of mud and heated with wood. He sells each bread for 5 PKRs. He is well known for his quality work and gets regular orders. He has 15 years of experience in this work. Fatima has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband’s business. He will use the loan amount to buy flour in bulk and increase his business income. Fatima hopes that by making positive use of the loan, her husband will be able to improve his business and she will be able to send her children to school soon.

Fatima is a regular lender with Asasah and is in her third loan cycle. In previous loan years, she has proved herself to be a responsible client; she never missed any meeting and paid her installments on time.

loans.use: to purchase flour in bulk for a bread-making and selling business

loans.name: Siaka

texts.fr:
Monsieur Siaka Traoré est un homme marié de 31 ans et père de 2 enfants. Il vit avec sa femme et ses enfants chez son oncle à Bougouni dans le quartier Torakabougou.
Ayant vite abandonné l’école dès son jeune âge, il décida d’apprendre le métier de tailleur auprès de son oncle.
Il a 10 années d’expérience dans ce domaine qu’il maîtrise bien. En plus de ses prestations de couture, il vend actuellement les matériels que les tailleurs et couturiers utilisent fréquemment.
Pour renforcer ses activités, il décida d’intégrer le programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso  avec qui il est à sa première expérience.
Avec ce prêt il compte acheter, des tissus, boutons, chaînes, fil, aiguilles etc pour les revendre à une clientèle composée de tailleurs et  couturiers.
Il s’approvisionne à Bougouni et à Bamako (Capitale de république du Mali).
Les fêtes religieuses constituent les moments où il y a plus de ventes. 
Il  compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de  40 500 FCFA.
Avec ce bénéfice il compte améliorer son atelier afin d’attirer les clients, contribuer aux dépenses de la famille et ouvrir un autre atelier.
texts.en:
Mr. Siaka Traoré is 31 years old, married and the father of two children. He lives with his wife and children in his uncle’s home in the Torakabougou borough of Bougouni. Having stopped going to school at an early age, he decided to learn the tailoring trade from his uncle. He now has ten years’ experience in this activity which he masters well. In addition to his tailoring activity, he also sells material often used by tailors and dressmakers. To strengthen his business he decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan programme where this will be his first experience. With the loan he wants to buy fabric, buttons, chains, thread, needles, etc., for resale to a customer base of tailors and dressmakers. He gets his supplies from Bougouni and Bamoko (capital of the Republic of Mali). Religious festivities are the time when sales are at their peak. He is counting on monthly earnings of 40,500 FCFA. With his earnings he will make improvements to his workshop to attract customers, contribute towards family expenses and open another workshop.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy sewing material

loans.name: Annie

texts.en:
Annie E. lives with her family in the province of Antique in the Philippines. Her husband works long hours as a fisherman to support the family. 

To supply additional income, Annie would like to receive a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to purchase raw materials needed in her fishing business, such as fishing net, and for the maintenance of her fishing boat. With more fish to catch and sell, Annie believes that sales will increase, leading to higher revenue.  

As a dedicated member of Kiva partner ASHI, she ensured strong performance with regular attendance at group meetings and steady repayments. Annie is thankful for access to capital and loans to support her entrepreneurial dreams. With the support of ASHI and Kiva, she is hopeful that her business will continue to flourish to improve the family’s quality of life and fund all of her children’s educations until they finish college.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials needed in her fishing business, such as fishing net, and for the maintenance of her fishing boat

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty J. is currently in the business of operating a small business selling clothes at the market. She is requesting a loan so she can stock more clothes to sell. Betty is 29 years old and is married with a husband who is a businessman. She has four children, three of whom go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Benigna

texts.es:
Benigna es socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres Clavelinas”, ubicado en el distrito de Ilave, provincia de EL Collao, Departamento de Puno, tiene36 años de edad, de estado civil conviviente, con  seis  hijos, tiene grado de instrucción secundaria completa.
Benigna viene trabajando con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace 2 años, el primer préstamo solicitado fue de S/300.00 nuevo soles, préstamo que  sirvió para la compra y engorde de animales menores como cerdos y ovejas.
Ahora solicitará un nuevo préstamo de S/ 2500.00 nuevo soles, dinero que le servirá para incrementar el capital de  su negocio,  no solamente de animales menores sino también de mayores como el engorde de ganado vacuno.
Su sueño es que su negocio sea más grande y que pueda convertirse en una mayorista.
Lo que le gusta del Banco Comunal son las ganancias del ahorro y las charlas realizadas por la promotora.
texts.en:
Benigna is a member of the community bank named "Mujeres Clavelinas". It is located in the district of Ilave of the province of Colla in Puno. She is 36 years old and she lives with her common-law partner and their six children. She is a high school graduate.

Benigna has been a member of the Manuela Ramos movement (Kiva Field Partner) for the past 2 years. The first loan she requested was in the amount of 300 nuevos soles and it was invested in the purchase of livestock, such as pigs and sheep. 

She requests a new loan in the amount of 2500 nuevos soles to use as working capital for her business. She wants to raise not only small livestock animals but cattle as well. 

Her dream is to see her business expand and become a wholesaler.  What she most enjoys about her community bank is the ability to save money and the talks that are given by the facilitators.

loans.use: To expand the herd of cattle.

loans.name: Assia Bibe Aida

texts.pt:
Assia Bibe Aida I. conseguiu comprar o material acordado embora não na totalidade devido ao elevado custo de material, mas conseguiu algum auxílio para poder concretizar o seu objectivo. 

Conseguiu pagar o valor sem problemas, embora com alguns atrasos devido ao seu vencimento que saía tarde e sendo a única fonte de rendimento devia esperar ate o vencimento sair. A sua obra esta neste momento numa fase muita avancada,com o presente emprestimo no valor de 15.000.00mt pretende comprar material de construcao (cimento, pedra, legalizacao do terreno e outros)para dar continuidade com a sua obra. 

Houve certas mudanças na sua vida, já esta a concluir uma casa própria e no futuro pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para construir a sua casa.
texts.en:
Assia Bibe Aida I. was able to buy the material expected although not all of it, due to the high price of the material, but she was able to get some help to accomplish her objective.

She was able to pay the price without problem, with some delays due to delays on her salary and because she is the only source of income she had to wait until she got paid in order to pay off the materials. Her construction is now very advanced, with the current loan for 15,000mt she expect to buy construction material (cement, stone, to legalize her land, among others) to keep on going the construction.

She is getting close to finish building her house and expects to request another loan to fulfill this.

loans.use: buy construction material (cement, stone, to legalize her land, among others)

loans.name: Inkundamahoro Group

texts.fr: Deo Mussa N. est commerçant, et il est un membre du groupe Inkunsamahoro.  Il est marié, et il n’a pas d’enfants.  Avec son prêt, il veut acheter les sorghos et haricots pour les détailler en sa boutique.  Sa stratégie pour la croissance de l’affaire est d’épargne sur le compte dans deux semaines.  Il voudrait avoir la capacité d’autofinancement.  Pour sa famille, il voudrait satisfaire leur besoins.
texts.en: Deo Mussa N. is a merchant. He is a member of Inkundamahoro Group. He is married without children. He wants to use his loan to buy sorghum and beans and retail them in his store. The growth strategy of his business is to save money in his account within two weeks. He would like his business to become self-financing. He wants to provide for the needs of his family.

loans.use: To buy sorghum and beans

loans.name: Mili

texts.en:
Mili chose a challenging time to start up his business, ‘Yes V Can’: “I registered the company at City Hall on a rainy Friday the 13th in February of 2009,” he describes. 

Despite his launching the business at the height of the recession, Yes V Can is growing. Mili explains that an old saying – “Greatness requires the taking of risks. That is why so few ever achieve it,” – inspires him to take on the challenges of owning a small business. Yes V Can provides copying, printing, binding, and other services for large construction projects, and Mili’s signs - like those used to indicate projects that have received American Recovery Reinvestment Act funding - can be seen around the San Francisco Bay Area.

Mili prides himself on thinking outside the box to keep prices low. Recently, he successfully out-bid a large corporation for a banner project in San Francisco’s Bayview neighborhood, where his shop is located. While the corporation sought to lower prices by purchasing metal brackets made in China, Mili employed an acquaintance to turn out the brackets locally. Mili kept the job local, and his fixtures were cheaper and stronger. 

Looking forward, Mili would like to be a ‘one-stop shop’ for all construction companies and walk-in customers who need his services. “Finding customers and building trust is the difficult part,” he explains. “Once I find them, I want to progress through the project with the customer.” 

When Mili started Yes V Can he needed a large format printer, but without an established credit history he was unable to qualify for a loan from his bank or leasing company. Mili rented the machine from a competitor but was charged a crippling fee that was 400% above market rate. Fortunately, he was recently presented with the chance to buy his own machine and came to his local MFI, Opportunity Fund, for financing. 

“I was in a quandary over what to do. Then I heard about Opportunity Fund, and within 2 weeks I was approved for a loan. This is a really good thing.” A $5,000 loan will cover the cost of two used printers, which will allow him to take on more jobs, be more cost-effective, and grow his business. In the near future, he plans to hire an employee to help manage his increasing workload. 

Ultimately, Mili’s goal is to help and hire from his community. “It’s through the community that I’ve been able to do this so far – showing gratitude and giving back is very important. That’s how I was raised by my parents, and I want to live by their example so my children will do the same when it is time for them to face the world!”

loans.use: Cover the cost of two used printers

loans.name: Emilio

texts.es:
El señor Emilio Rodríguez tiene 25 años y está casado por más de 5 años con la señora Ivana Medrano Mamani, tienen 2 hijos pequeños los cuales acuden a una escuelita de la zona por las mañanas. Emilio vive en la Zona conocida como Zofraco en el barrio Monte Canto en Cochabamba, donde tiene vacas, cuya leche vende a una empresa que se encarga de elaborar diferentes productos lácteos.

Emilio es una persona joven que quiere incrementar poco a poco la cantidad de ganado lechero que tiene y de esa manera poder incrementar su producción de leche cruda aun mas. Emilio espera poder obtener este préstamo para poder comprar una vaca lechera mas y aumentar su producción de leche y así sus ingresos, y agradece mucho a la gente que por medio se kiva le pudo dar la oportunidad de superarse con la compra de una vaca y espera le puedan depositar en él su confianza una vez más.

Emilio nos cuenta que en un futuro quisiera sacar un nuevo préstamo para poder construir un establo para poder alojar a su ganado y de esa manera estén más protegidos en la temporada de lluvia.
texts.en:
Emilio is 25 years old and married for more than 5 years to Ivana.  They have 2 small children who attend a little school in their zone during mornings. Emilio lives in the zone known as Zofraco, in Monte Canto barrio, Cochabamba, where he has cattle whose milk he sells to an enterprise that makes different milk products.

Emilio is a young person who wants to little by little increase his stock of milk cows and, in this way, to expand production of raw milk even more. Emilio hopes to obtain the loan so he can buy another milk cow and increase milk production and his income. He appreciates very much those who through Kiva are able to provide him an opportunity to advance with the purchase of a cow, and he hopes they will offer their confidence once again.

Emilio tells us that in the future, he wants to take out a new loan to be able to construct a stable in which he can lodge his cattle to protect them during the rainy season.

loans.use: TO BUY A MILK COW

loans.name: Jargal

texts.en: Jargal L., age 64, lives with her husband and son in her own house and enclosure in the Songino-Hairhan district of Ulaanbaatar. Her son works for a private company and her husband has retired on a pension. Jargal has operated a grocery sales business since 1992, renting a stall in “Tavan erdene”, a grocery market in her town. She has been paying 160,000 MNT a month to rent the stall. After many years of owning this business, she has gained a lot of experience as a businesswomen. Her income is around 130,000 MNT a day and 300,000-400,000 MNT a month. For the future, she plans to open a savings account for her son.
